metadata.titleEn: Field investigation of elements (carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, sulfur, potassium) of vegetation in the Water tower area of Qinghai Tibet Plateau and Himalayan Mountains (2020s)
metadata.description: Carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, sulfur and potassium are important basic life elements of ecosystem. It plays an important role in revealing the impact of its regional variation and spatial pattern on human activities and the sustainable development of ecosystem in the future. The Qinghai Tibet Plateau has unique alpine vegetation types and rich vertical zone landforms and surface cover types. The biogeographic pattern of surface elements (carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, sulfur, potassium) is an important manifestation of the coupling of carbon, nitrogen and water cycle processes and related mechanisms of alpine ecosystems. This dataset focuses on the distribution pattern and spatial variation of surface materials (plant leaf branch stem root and litter) in the complex ecosystem of the Water tower area of Qinghai Tibet Plateau and Himalayan Mountains, in order to provide data support for regional model simulation and ecological management.

background: Sulfur (S) is an essential macroelement in plant growth and development, with important biological functions such as catalysis, regulation, and structure. S is closely related to photosynthesis, biotic or abiotic stress resistance, and secondary metabolism. S in vegetation is mainly sourced from the soil, with a small amount absorbed from the atmosphere by leaves. Despite the importance of S for plants, information on the patterns of S storage in the vegetation of terrestrial ecosystems remains limited. It is largely unknown how global climate change affects the biogeographic patterns of S, especially at large geographic scales.
research objective: In this study, we systematically evaluated the S distribution patterns and storage in vegetation on the Tibetan Plateau for the first time, based on consistent field-measured data of 2,040 plant communities.
challenges: Due to the severe climatic conditions and inadequate transportation facilities on the Tibetan Plateau, we could not conduct random sampling during our field survey. Sampling was not conducted in the depopulated zone due to strict restrictions imposed by government policies and traffic problems.
methods: In this study, we used the grid method to investigate a total of 2,040 plant communities on the Tibetan Plateau and consistently measured the S content (g kg−1) and S density (t hm−2) in different plant organs. Field sampling was conducted during the peak plant growth period (July–August) in 2019–2020. The Tibetan Plateau was sampled on a grid basis (the plateau was divided into 0.5° × 0.5° geographic grids), with three randomly set sample squares in each grid. In each grid, a stratified survey was used to investigate the community structure of the forests, shrubland, grasslands, and deserts. Three sample plots were randomly set up for sampling trees (20 × 20 m), shrubs (20 × 20 m), and herbs (1 × 1 m), respectively. Well-grown tree plants in (or around) the sample plots were selected, and top sunny branches (diameter <1 cm) were collected using high branch scissors; subsequently, healthy, fully expanded leaves free of diseases and insects were hand-picked to form mixed leaf or fine branch samples for each sample plot, respectively. Growth cones were used to collect tree core samples; at the same time, intact fine roots (diameter <2 mm) were excavated along the lateral roots. For each shrub species, 1–3 healthy plants were selected in each sample plot, and the top branches of the canopy were intercepted using high-branch scissors to obtain mixed samples of leaves and branches, respectively; meanwhile, the shrub roots were obtained through excavation. Three mixed samples of leaves, branches, trunks, and roots of different species were obtained for each sample plot. Within each sample plot, 5–30 plants of each herbaceous species were selected, and above-ground (leaves and stems) and below-ground (roots) were collected. We mixed the above-ground and below-ground samples of different species within each grassland sample plot separately and evenly to obtain three mixed samples each. For each sample plot, soil samples were collected from 30 to 50 randomly selected points in the 0–10 cm surface layer using a soil sampler and mixed thoroughly to obtain three mixed samples. We collected 5,360 plant samples and 2,040 soil samples in total. A standard method was used to measure the S content (g kg−1) in leaves (Sleaf), branches (Sbranch), trunks (Strunk), and roots (Sroot). First, the surfaces of different plant organ samples were cleaned and then dried to a constant weight at 65°C for 48 hr. Soil samples were air-dried and sieved using a 2 mm mesh to remove stones and roots. Then, all plant and soil samples were finely ground using an agate mortar grinder (RM200; Retsch, Haan, Germany) and a ball mill (MM400 Ball Mill; Retsch). All plant samples were digested using a microwave digestion system (CEM, Matthews, NC, USA) before analysis. GBW10020 (GSB-11 Citrus leaf) and GBW07407a (GSS-7a) were used as Certified Reference Material for the measurement of plant S content, respectively. Finally, an inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP-OES; Optima Avio 500, Perkin Elmer, Waltham, MA, USA) was used to measure the S content in plant samples.
dataset: In this study, we systematically evaluated the S distribution patterns and storage in vegetation on the Tibetan Plateau for the first time, based on consistent field-measured data of 2,040 plant communities.
findings: The mean S contents of leaves, branches, trunks, and roots were 1.68, 0.40, 0.19, and 1.45 g kg −1, respectively; corresponding to S densities of 0.40 × 10 −2 (9.57%), 1.18 × 10 −2 (28.38%), 1.37 × 10 −2 (32.90%) and 1.21 × 10 −2 t hm −2 (29.15%), respectively. The mean S densities for forests (5.59 ± 0.26 × 10 −2 t hm −2) were higher than that of shrublands (4.54 ± 0.51 × 10 −2 t hm −2), grasslands (1.03 ± 0.07 × 10 −2 t hm −2), and deserts (1.32 ± 0.28 × 10 −2 t hm −2). The S density was generally lower in the northwest and higher in the southeast of the Tibetan Plateau and had divergent allocation patterns between different plant organs and vegetation types. Furthermore, we found that S in leaves and roots was more strongly influenced by environmental factors and was particularly sensitive to radiation and atmospheric pressure. Moreover, the total S storage in the vegetation of the Tibetan Plateau was estimated to be 337.32 × 10 4 t, with 114.32 × 10 4 (33.89%), 92.36 × 10 4 (27.38%), 128.77 × 10 4 (38.17%), and 1.86 × 10 4 t (0.55%) in the forests, shrublands, grasslands, and deserts, respectively.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to measure sulfur content in vegetation in a large geographic area like the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: One example of a data collection method used to measure sulfur content in vegetation on the Tibetan Plateau involved using a grid method to systematically evaluate 2,040 plant communities. The process included stratified surveys of community structures in forests, shrublands, grasslands, and deserts, with specific sampling techniques for trees, shrubs, and herbs, followed by the use of inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) to measure sulfur content.

Example.Question: Could you illustrate a challenge encountered in collecting biogeographic data on the Tibetan Plateau and how it was addressed?
Example.Answer: A challenge in collecting biogeographic data on the Tibetan Plateau was the severe climatic conditions and inadequate transportation facilities, which restricted random sampling and access to certain zones due to government policies and traffic issues. This was addressed by employing a structured grid method for sampling and selecting sample plots that were accessible, allowing for consistent data collection despite logistical constraints.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset that provides insights into the distribution patterns of sulfur in vegetation across diverse ecosystems in a mountainous region?
Example.Answer: An example of such a dataset is one that evaluated sulfur distribution patterns and storage in vegetation on the Tibetan Plateau. It was based on consistent field-measured data from 2,040 plant communities, covering different vegetation types like forests, shrublands, grasslands, and deserts, and included measurements of sulfur content and density in various plant organs.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'grid method' in the context of ecological data collection on the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: The 'grid method' in this context refers to dividing the Tibetan Plateau into geographic grids, specifically 0.5° × 0.5° grids, and systematically sampling plant communities within these grids. This approach ensures consistent data collection across various plant communities by setting three randomly selected sample squares within each grid, facilitating the investigation of community structures across different vegetation types.

Definition.Question: What does 'standard method' entail for measuring sulfur content in plant samples?
Definition.Answer: The 'standard method' for measuring sulfur content in plant samples involves cleaning plant organ samples, drying them to a constant weight at 65°C for 48 hours, and processing them through grinding and digestion. The sulfur content is then measured using an inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP-OES), ensuring accurate and reliable sulfur quantification in the samples.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'stratified survey' in researching biogeographic patterns on the Tibetan Plateau?
Definition.Answer: A 'stratified survey' in this context is significant as it allows researchers to systematically investigate the community structure across various vegetation types such as forests, shrublands, grasslands, and deserts. This method enhances the understanding of biogeographic patterns by ensuring representative sampling of different ecological strata, which is crucial for analyzing spatial distribution and variation in elemental content across the plateau.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the spatial patterns of sulfur distribution in Tibetan Plateau vegetation differ from those observed in other biogeographic regions?
Comparison.Answer: The spatial patterns of sulfur distribution in Tibetan Plateau vegetation show divergent allocation patterns between different plant organs and vegetation types, with higher S densities in the southeast compared to the northwest. This distribution might differ from other biogeographic regions, where environmental factors such as radiation and atmospheric pressure, which strongly influence sulfur in leaves and roots, could lead to different spatial patterns.

Interpretation.Question: How do the observed spatial patterns of sulfur storage in vegetation on the Tibetan Plateau reflect the influence of environmental factors such as radiation and atmospheric pressure?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial patterns of sulfur storage in vegetation on the Tibetan Plateau indicate that sulfur in leaves and roots is more strongly influenced by environmental factors, particularly radiation and atmospheric pressure. This suggests that these environmental conditions play a significant role in the biogeographic distribution of sulfur within different plant organs and vegetation types.

Interpretation.Question: What can the allocation patterns of sulfur in different vegetation types, such as forests, shrublands, grasslands, and deserts, infer about the ecological adaptations of these ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: The allocation patterns of sulfur in different vegetation types suggest that forests tend to have higher sulfur densities compared to shrublands, grasslands, and deserts. This may infer that forests have adapted to store more sulfur, possibly due to their more complex structure and higher biomass, which could be a response to environmental pressures or nutrient availability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in conducting random sampling in high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in conducting random sampling in high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau are primarily due to severe climatic conditions and inadequate transportation facilities. Additionally, strict restrictions imposed by government policies and traffic problems limit access, particularly in depopulated zones.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it important to consider environmental factors when analyzing sulfur distribution in different plant organs in the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Considering environmental factors is important when analyzing sulfur distribution in different plant organs because sulfur in leaves and roots is strongly influenced by environmental conditions, particularly radiation and atmospheric pressure. These factors can significantly affect the biogeographic patterns of sulfur allocation in vegetation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of implementing a grid-based sampling method for studying vegetation distribution in high-altitude ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a grid-based sampling method allows for a systematic evaluation of vegetation distribution patterns and storage, providing consistent field-measured data across a large geographic scale. This method can help identify biogeographic patterns and spatial variations in essential elements like sulfur, which are crucial for understanding ecosystem processes and the impact of environmental factors.

Causal Consequence.Question: How do the limitations imposed by severe climatic conditions and transportation challenges impact the data collection process on the Tibetan Plateau?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Severe climatic conditions and transportation challenges on the Tibetan Plateau hinder random sampling during field surveys. These limitations necessitate the use of alternative data collection methods, like grid-based sampling, to ensure comprehensive coverage while adhering to logistical constraints, thus affecting the spatial distribution and precision of the collected data.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective behind collecting data on the distribution patterns and storage of essential macroelements like sulfur in vegetation across the Tibetan Plateau?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to systematically evaluate sulfur distribution patterns and storage in vegetation on the Tibetan Plateau, based on field-measured data from 2,040 plant communities, to better understand how global climate change affects these biogeographic patterns at large geographic scales.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to investigate the spatial variation of surface elements such as carbon, nitrogen, phosphorus, sulfur, and potassium in the complex ecosystems of the Tibetan Plateau and Himalayan regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Investigating the spatial variation of these surface elements is important because they are fundamental life elements in ecosystems, and understanding their regional variation and spatial patterns is crucial for assessing the impact of human activities and ensuring the future sustainable development of these ecosystems.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the motivation for using a grid-based sampling method in evaluating plant communities on the Tibetan Plateau for sulfur content and density?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The motivation for using a grid-based sampling method is to ensure consistent and systematic evaluation of sulfur content and density across different plant communities on the Tibetan Plateau, despite challenges such as severe climatic conditions and inadequate transportation facilities, which restrict random sampling and access to certain areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are plant and soil samples prepared and processed to measure sulfur content in a biogeographic study?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Plant organ samples are cleaned, dried, and ground to a fine consistency. Soil samples are air-dried, sieved, and ground as well. Plant samples are digested using a microwave digestion system before analysis. Certified Reference Materials are used for accurate measurement of sulfur content using an inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP-OES).

Enablement.Question: What sampling techniques enable the collection of comprehensive vegetation sulfur content data across diverse plant communities on the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The grid method, stratified survey, and random setting of sample plots enabled comprehensive vegetation sulfur content data collection. Specifically, the plateau was divided into 0.5° × 0.5° geographic grids with three randomly set sample squares in each grid, and different community structures like forests, shrublands, grasslands, and deserts were surveyed using stratified sampling.

Enablement.Question: How do technological tools enhance the precision of sulfur content measurement in plant and soil samples on the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: Technological tools such as a microwave digestion system, an inductively coupled plasma emission spectrometer (ICP-OES), and grinding equipment like an agate mortar grinder and a ball mill enhance precision in measuring sulfur content. These tools allow for thorough digestion, fine grinding, and accurate spectral analysis of plant and soil samples.

Expectation.Question: What challenges could be anticipated in collecting consistent sulfur content data across different plant organs in remote high-altitude regions like the Tibetan Plateau?
Expectation.Answer: Challenges in collecting consistent sulfur content data across different plant organs in remote high-altitude regions include severe climatic conditions, which can affect the accessibility and safety of fieldwork. Inadequate transportation facilities may limit the ability to reach certain areas, and government-imposed restrictions can prevent sampling in depopulated zones. These factors can lead to difficulties in obtaining a representative sample and ensuring consistency in data collection.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be important to expect variability in sulfur density among different vegetation types when studying the Tibetan Plateau ecosystem?
Expectation.Answer: It is important to expect variability in sulfur density among different vegetation types because each type may have distinct ecological characteristics and interactions with environmental factors. For example, forests, shrublands, grasslands, and deserts have different plant structures and biomass, which can lead to varying sulfur storage capacities. Additionally, environmental factors such as radiation and atmospheric pressure can differently influence sulfur content in plant organs like leaves and roots, contributing to the observed variability.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using a grid method for sampling plant communities in mountainous regions with severe climatic conditions?
Judgmental.Answer: The grid method appears to be effective in systematically covering large geographic scales, like the Tibetan Plateau, despite severe climatic conditions. It allows for consistent sampling across diverse ecosystems, ensuring varied data collection from forests, shrublands, grasslands, and deserts. However, restricted areas and challenging logistics may limit random sampling, which could impact the representativeness of the data.

Assertion.Answer: Due to severe climatic conditions and inadequate transportation facilities, random sampling was not feasible. Instead, a grid method was used, where the plateau was divided into 0.5° × 0.5° geographic grids, and three randomly set sample squares were sampled within each grid during the peak plant growth period. Stratified surveys were conducted for different vegetation types, and specific methods like selecting well-grown tree plants and using high branch scissors were employed for sample collection.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how a dataset can provide insights into the spatial variability of essential elements like sulfur in such a complex ecosystem.
Assertion.Answer: The dataset provides insights by systematically evaluating sulfur distribution patterns and storage in vegetation across 2,040 plant communities on the Tibetan Plateau. The study measures sulfur content in different plant organs and uses these measurements to reveal regional variations and spatial patterns of sulfur, showing how it is affected by environmental factors like radiation and atmospheric pressure.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies for expanding datasets related to plant sulfur content across different vegetation types while ensuring data consistency and reliability.
Request/Directive.Answer: Strategies for expanding datasets could include integrating remote sensing data to cover inaccessible areas, collaborating with local research institutions to enhance geographic coverage, and employing standardized protocols for sample collection and analysis to maintain consistency. Additionally, establishing a centralized database for sharing data among researchers could improve dataset reliability and accessibility.
